reader-objects_key3: To read data from a CSV `file` with the csv module, you need to create a Reader object. A Reader object lets you iterate over lines in the CSV `file`. Enter the following into the interactive `shell`, with example.csv in the current working directory:
reader-objects_key5: To read a CSV `file` with the csv module, first open it using the open() function ❷, just as you would any other text `file`. But instead of calling the read() or readlines() method on the `File` object that open() returns, pass it to the csv.reader() function ❸. This will return a Reader object for you to use. Note that you don’t pass a `file`name `string` directly to the csv.reader() function.
reader-objects_key6: The most direct way to access the values in the Reader object is to convert it to a plain `Python` list by passing it to list() ❹. Using list() on this Reader object returns a list of lists, which you can store in a `variable` like exampleData. Entering exampleData in the `shell` displays the list of lists ❺.
reader-objects_key7: Now that you have the CSV `file` as a list of lists, you can access the value at a particular row and column with the expression exampleData[row][col], where row is the index of one of the lists in exampleData, and col is the index of the item you want from that list. Enter the following into the interactive `shell`:
reader-objects_key12:
'Strawberries'
exampleData[0][0] goes into the first list and gives us the first `string`, exampleData[0][2] goes into the first list and gives us the third `string`, and so on.
